unnormalised: New Delhi: Concerns are rising among medical professionals regarding the increasing rates of pre-eclampsia in expecting mothers, particularly those in urban areas. A recent study conducted at AIIMS, Delhi, revealed that approx. 15% of pregnant women attending the antenatal clinic were diagnosed with some form of hypertensive disorder, with pre-eclampsia being the most prevalent. This is a sig. increase compared to data from 5 yrs ago.
normalised: New Delhi: Concerns are rising among medical professionals regarding the increasing rates of pre-eclampsia in expecting mothers, particularly those in urban areas. A recent study conducted at A-I-I-M-S, Delhi, revealed that approximately fifteen percent of pregnant women attending the antenatal clinic were diagnosed with some form of hypertensive disorder, with pre-eclampsia being the most prevalent. This is a significant increase compared to data from five years ago.

unnormalised: Dr. Aisha Khan, Head of the Obstetrics and Gynecology dept. at Max Hospital, emphasizes the importance of early detection. "Regular prenatal check-ups are crucial. We advise expecting mothers to attend at least 4 ANC visits during their pregnancy. Early detection of elevated BP allows for timely intervention and reduces the risk of severe complications. Remember 140/90 mmHg is the cut off."

We advise expecting mothers to attend at least four A-N-C visits during their pregnancy. Early detection of elevated B-P allows for timely intervention and reduces the risk of severe complications. Remember one hundred and forty divided by ninety millimeters of mercury is the cut off."

unnormalised: Contributing factors include lifestyle changes, delayed pregnancies, and a rise in obesity rates among women of reproductive age. Experts are also investigating possible links to environmental factors and dietary habits. Dr. Patel at Fortis Healthcare mentioned in a recent conference that studies are being done at his facility that look at the role of Vitamin D levels and their link to hypertensive disorders in pregnancy. Initial findings indicate a correlation, but more data is needed.

unnormalised: Pre-eclampsia, if left untreated, can lead to serious complications for both the mother and the baby, incl. preterm labor, seizures, and even maternal death. Symptoms can include severe headaches, visual disturbances, and swelling in the hands and feet. Treatment options range from medication to manage blood pressure to early delivery in severe cases. Some insurance covers maternity costs upto Rs. 50000.

unnormalised: The Indian Medical Association (IMA) is urging increased awareness and education among expecting mothers regarding the risks and prevention of pre-eclampsia. A national campaign is planned for next year targeting high-risk populations with the goal to reduce maternal and fetal morbidity associated with this condition. They plan to launch it on the 14/11/2025.
